Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Story: As I sat at the dinner table, my family’s voices buzzed around me, tossing out ideas for our weekend together. My little sister’s eyes sparkled as she begged me to join the hiking trip, and my parents looked at me expectantly, waiting for my input. I knew how much it meant to them when I was present, really present, during these rare moments we all had together. Just as I was about to chime in, my phone vibrated. It was my best friend, Sam. The message was short: “Can you talk? I really need you.” I could hear the strain in his voice when I picked up—he was on the verge of tears, desperate for someone to listen as he poured out the details of a fight with his partner. My family’s laughter echoed in the background, and I felt the weight of their expectations pressing on me. I wanted to be the supportive brother they counted on, but I also knew Sam needed me now more than ever. My heart pounded as I sat there, torn between two worlds, unsure which one I was about to let down.
